awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Engineering Charge Transport through Directed Orientation of Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will investigate new materials and catalyst structures for the efficient photocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis of chemical reactions of importance for the production of clean energy from the sun and other renewable or sustainable resources. The research will also have applicability to a number of technologies of importance to the Nation's economic competitiveness and resource utilization, including energy storage, photovoltaics, and optoelectronics.  In addition, educational and outreach activities will be incorporated, including both graduate and undergraduate student training, a K-12 workshop on interactive photocatalytic energy conversion, and summer research opportunities for high-school students.
 
The project investigates the transition metal dichalcogenide (TMDC) catalyst tungsten disulfide (WS2) for the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction and the photocatalytic reduction of water to produce hydrogen as a renewable component of fuels and chemicals.  Specifically, a unique edge-on orientation of the nanoscale WS2 catalyst particles with respect to their supporting charge transfer material will be investigated to achieve dramatically higher reaction rates than obtainable with conventional flat particle oriented catalysts. The dichalcogenides are known to be active due to the high catalytic activity of their edge sites when supported on a semiconductor, metal, or carbon material.  Maximization of performance in these applications requires rapid charge transfer across the TMDC/support interface. However, for the typical orientations of TMDCs in most electro- and photocatalysts, the interfacial charge transfer is especially slow, since it must occur across the inert TMDC basal plane.  The research will test the hypothesis that the rates of charge transfer across the WS2-support interface will be increased by an edge-on orientation of the WS2 layers due to interfacial bonding, and that this rate can be tuned by controlling the edge termination of the WS2 layers.  The study will build upon the investigators' preliminary results showing promising photocatalytic activity of WS2 nanotube-arrays, in which the WS2 layers are in an edge-on orientation. These WS2 nanotubes will be used as a platform to design and synthesize novel Janus-type photoelectrodes and photocatalyst particles containing tailored interfaces. To gain fundamental understanding of these interfaces and guide their design, the investigators have prepared model systems consisting of WS2 single-crystals in either a basal plane or edge-on orientation. They will create WS2-semiconductor, metal or carbon interfaces by depositing these materials on top of the model WS2 systems and will measure the influence of WS2 orientation, defects, and edge termination on charge transfer and recombination rates at the interface. They will also perform measurements and modeling to understand these rates in terms of underlying factors including interfacial bonding and separation distance, interfacial dangling bonds and their electronic energies, and step changes in electrical potential energy and local electric field at the interface.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits

This project has developed new catalysts consisting of two-dimensional materials including tin disulfide and molybdenum disulfide, in the form of vertically-oriented nanoscale flakes (nanoflakes) grown by the reaction and condensation of vapors onto solid surfaces.

The vertical tin disulfide nanoflakes showed the highest performance to date as photo-electrocatalysts, which are catalysts that use sunlight and electricity to drive a chemical reaction. The high performance of these nanoflakes is due to their vertical orientation, their optimized height, and their unique stepped shape, with the step edges behaving as catalytically-active sites. Furthermore, calculations showed that the edges of the tin disulfide nanoflakes have special properties that should enable the efficient usage of solar energy to drive chemical reactions.

The vertical molybdenum disulfide nanoflakes showed high performance as electrocatalysts, which are catalysts that use electricity to drive a chemical reaction. In this case, these catalysts are used to evolve hydrogen gas from water. The vertical molybdenum disulfide nanoflakes have been synthesized on economical molybdenum and carbon substrates, rather than on more expensive gold substrates that were previously demonstrated. These nanoflakes show performance comparable to those grown on gold substrates, and superior performance compared to horizontally-oriented nanoflakes.

Broader Impacts

Renewable energy resources such as solar and wind have the potential to supply major portions of our energy needs. However, to successfully harness these resources on a large scale, we must be able to use them to efficiently and inexpensively produce valuable chemicals and zero-carbon or carbon-neutral fuels. The vertical tin disulfide nanoflakes developed here may find future application as catalysts for useful reactions such as solar-driven water decontamination or as electrodes in certain types of solar cells for electricity production. The vertical molybdenum sulfide nanoflakes developed here may find future application as catalysts in electrolyzers for the production of hydrogen from water, replacing the expensive platinum catalysts being used currently. The hydrogen can be used to drive fuel cells that power electric vehicles or buildings, or to produce fertilizers, as part of a zero-carbon infrastructure. The results of this work can therefore contribute towards the mitigation of global warming and pollution, and can therefore serve as a benefit to all members of society. Moreover, the resulting technologies can improve US energy security and economic competitiveness without relying on imports of energy or rare elements.


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Pratap M Rao
